title: Problem Introduction
content:
**Erd≈ës Problem #475: Graham's Rearrangement Conjecture**

Given a non-zero subset A of ùîΩ‚Çö, can we always arrange it as a‚ÇÅ, ..., a‚Çú so all partial sums are distinct?

**Status:** OPEN in general; proven for various ranges of t.

This is a fundamental problem in additive combinatorics, connecting prime fields, sequencing, and partial sums.
mathContext: The problem asks about the existence of special orderings. Among t! possible orderings, we need just one where no two partial sums coincide.

title: Partial Sums
content:
**partialSums l:**

The sequence of cumulative sums of a list l.

For l = [a‚ÇÅ, a‚ÇÇ, ..., a‚Çú], the partial sums are:
- a‚ÇÅ
- a‚ÇÅ + a‚ÇÇ
- a‚ÇÅ + a‚ÇÇ + a‚ÇÉ
- ...
- a‚ÇÅ + ... + a‚Çú

We need all t of these to be distinct.
mathContext: Implemented using List.scanl for accumulation, then dropping the initial 0.

title: Valid Ordering
content:
**IsValidOrdering A ordering:**

An ordering of set A is valid if:
1. The ordering contains exactly the elements of A (no duplicates, same set)
2. All partial sums of the ordering are distinct

This is the central property we seek to guarantee.
mathContext: Valid orderings are also called 'sequencings' in the literature on cyclic groups.

title: Graham's Conjecture
content:
**GrahamConjecture p:**

For prime p, every finite subset A ‚äÜ ùîΩ‚Çö \ {0} has a valid ordering.

The non-zero condition is essential: if 0 ‚àà A, any partial sum containing 0 could cause collisions.
mathContext: The conjecture is strongest when A is large (near p elements) since there are fewer possible sum values.

title: Small Cases: t ‚â§ 12
content:
**costa_pellegrini_2020:**

For |A| ‚â§ 12, valid orderings exist.

This was verified through a combination of:
- Exhaustive computation for specific primes
- Theoretical arguments reducing to manageable cases

Costa and Pellegrini (2020) established this systematically.
mathContext: Small cases often require checking t! orderings, but structure can reduce this.

title: Large Cases: t ‚â• p - 3
content:
**hicks_ollis_schmitt_2019 and graham_full_set:**

For sets of size p - 3, p - 2, or p - 1 (near-complete sets), valid orderings exist.

Graham originally proved t = p - 1. Hicks-Ollis-Schmitt extended this to p - 3.

**Intuition:** When A is almost all of ùîΩ‚Çö \ {0}, there's enough structure to guarantee valid orderings.
mathContext: Large sets have limited missing elements, constraining the problem sufficiently.

title: Logarithmic Range: t ‚â§ log p / log log p
content:
**kravitz_2024:**

For |A| ‚â§ log p / log log p, valid orderings exist.

This was proven by Kravitz in 2024 (and independently observed by Will Sawin on MathOverflow).

This significantly extends beyond the constant bound of 12.
mathContext: The log p / log log p bound grows slowly but unboundedly with p.

title: Beyond the Rectification Barrier
content:
**bedert_kravitz_2024:**

For |A| ‚â§ exp((log p)^{1/4}), valid orderings exist.

This is a major breakthrough! The 'rectification barrier' at log p / log log p was a technical obstacle that previous methods couldn't overcome.

Bedert and Kravitz (2024) developed new techniques to go far beyond this barrier.
mathContext: exp((log p)^{1/4}) grows much faster than log p / log log p, representing a substantial improvement.

title: Alspach's Conjecture
content:
**AlspachConjecture G:**

For ANY finite abelian group G, every non-zero subset has a valid ordering.

This generalizes Graham's conjecture from ùîΩ‚Çö to all abelian groups.

**graham_is_alspach_for_prime_field:** Graham's conjecture is exactly Alspach's for G = ùîΩ‚Çö.
mathContext: Alspach's more general conjecture remains open even for cyclic groups ‚Ñ§/n‚Ñ§ with composite n.

title: Constructive vs Existential
content:
**HasExplicitValidOrdering:**

Some proofs are constructive (giving explicit orderings), others are existential.

- Graham's original proof for t = p - 1 was constructive
- Small cases can be verified by explicit computation
- Some proofs use probabilistic or counting arguments (non-constructive)
mathContext: Constructive proofs are algorithmically useful; existential proofs establish truth without explicit examples.

title: Why This Problem is Hard
content:
**Challenge Analysis:**

1. **Factorial Search Space:** There are t! orderings to potentially check.

2. **Collision Avoidance:** We need t distinct values among p possible sums.

3. **Non-Local Constraint:** Whether partial sums collide depends on the full ordering.

4. **General vs Specific:** We need it to work for ALL non-zero subsets A.
mathContext: The problem combines combinatorial explosion with global constraints, making brute force infeasible for large t.

title: Main Theorem Summary
content:
**erdos_475:**

Status of Graham's Conjecture:

**Proven for:**
- t ‚â§ 12 (Costa-Pellegrini)
- t ‚â• p - 3 (Hicks-Ollis-Schmitt)
- t ‚â§ exp((log p)^{1/4}) (Bedert-Kravitz)

**Open:** The general case, especially the 'gap' between exp((log p)^{1/4}) and p - 3.

The conjecture is expected to be true for all t.
mathContext: Progress has accelerated recently, with Bedert-Kravitz (2024) making a major breakthrough.
